A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

Let $G, G^{\'prime}$ be monoids with corresponding unit elements $e$ and $e^{\'prime}$. A monoid homomorphism $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\'prime}$ is a map $\varphi$ from $G$ to $G^{\'prime}$ such that (i) $\varphi(e)=e^{\'prime}$, (ii) $\varphi(a b)=\varphi(a) \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in G$.
The zero ring is a ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. It consists of a single element 0.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Galois Group of a Polynomial Splitting Fields
The Galois group of a polynomial equation is the group of automorphisms of the splitting field of the polynomial that fix the base field. These automorphisms permute the roots of the polynomial.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.
Let $G \times X \longrightarrow X$ be an action of a group $G$ on a set $X$. The orbit of a point $x \in X$ is defined as $G x:=\{g x ; g \in G\}$.
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
